hero.title: Build Your Own
hero.description: A complete step-by-step guide to building an ESP32-powered chess board, 100% DIY, with LED move indicators, hall-effect piece detection, Stockfish AI, and Lichess online play.

materials.toolsNote: Soldering iron, tape, glue, wire strippers, cutter, flush cutters, multimeter (optional but helpful to check connections and shorts).

sections.title: Schematics
sections.intro: These diagrams show how to connect all the electronic components together. Study and understand them before you start soldering.

steps.title: ESP32 + PCB Wiring
steps.description: Overview of the ESP32 connected to the main PCB - showing shift register signals, sensor rows/cols, LED data, pull-up resistors and power lines.

steps.title: Plastic PCB Wiring
steps.description: DIY plastic PCB wiring, 3D model on MakerWorld.

steps.title: Transistor Circuits - Column Drivers
steps.description: PNP transistors should be used to switch 5V power to each sensor column via the shift register outputs. This prevents voltage drop and protects the shift register from overcurrent. If you don't use them, don't be surprised when the magnets aren't detected. I didn't use them for my own prototype because I just copied the original Concept-Bytes PCB 1:1, it luckily worked for me but as soon as other people started building it and having issues, that's when we realized the original PCB design is REALLY BAD !

steps.title: Original PCB Layout
steps.description: The original Concept-Bytes PCB design, useful if you want to connect the ESP32 to it

sections.title: Step 1 - PCB Overview
sections.intro: Get familiar with the main PCB before we start on the board itself. This is where the ESP32, shift register, transistors, and connectors live.

steps.title: PCB Bottom Side
steps.description: Build and test the PCB, following the schematics above. This is mine, notice it doesn't use transistors nor a level shifter, but they're highly recommended for reliability.

steps.title: PCB Top Side
steps.description: Top view of the PCB with and without the ESP32 mounted. GND and Shift Register QA are routed on this side.

images.caption: PCB top view with ESP32 mounted

steps.title: PCB Thickness Reference
steps.description: A sense of scale for the assembled PCB stack. Thicker might not fit under the board, especially if using the LED strip with spacers.

sections.title: Step 2 - LED Strip Installation
sections.intro: Glue the LEDs flush for even light diffusion without shadows. Cut the strip for easier installation, you'll reconnect it later and control it as one continuous strip in software. Test the strip with the ESP32 before cutting to ensure all LEDs work.

steps.title: Cut the LED Strip
steps.description: Cut the WS2812B LED strip at every 8th LED along the marked cut lines. You'll have 8 segments of 8 LEDs each (64 LEDs total)

steps.title: Glue Strip End
steps.description: Remove the bi-adhesive backing and glue the first LED into position: there is a notch in the plastic PCB indicating where the LED center should be placed. Start from one corner and make sure the data arrow direction is correct.

steps.title: Serpentine Routing
steps.description: Route the strips in a serpentine (zig-zag) pattern - each row reverses direction (critical for correct LED data signal flow). If you want to add spacers, now's the time to insert them between the strip and the board surface before pushing down on the glue.

steps.title: Strip Installation Complete
steps.description: Front and back views of the completed LED strip installation.

steps.title: With Spacers Installed
steps.description: The strip will have some slack which might cause accidental ungluing, to prevent it you can add spacers. Make sure your ESP32 PCB is thin enough to fit under the board with them in place.

sections.title: Step 3 - Sensor Placement
sections.intro: Install the A3144 hall-effect sensors - one per square, right next to each LED. These will detect the magnets embedded in the chess pieces.

steps.title: Apply Glue on Sensor Holder
steps.description: Put a small dab of glue where the sensor will sit.

steps.title: Place the Sensor
steps.description: Bend the A3144 sensor pins 90 degrees and place it on the holder as shown in the picture, pins should stick out the back.

steps.title: Push Sensor into Glue
steps.description: Press the sensor into the holder and glue.

steps.title: Reinforce with More Glue
steps.description: Add more glue around the sensor to secure it firmly, you don't want it moving around when you start soldering wires to it.

sections.title: Step 4 - Wiring: Ground (GND)
sections.intro: Run ground wires through the board's wire guides, connecting sensor GND pins and LED strip GND together. This creates a common ground reference for the entire board, which we then can easily insulate to avoid shorts with other wires we add later.

steps.title: Pass GND Wires Through Guides
steps.description: Thread the ground wires through the built-in wire guides on the board. These keep the wiring tidy and prevent shorts.

steps.title: Move Sensor GND Over Pin
steps.description: Bend the GND wires over the sensor's GND pins. This creates distance from the plastic and forces the wire to stay tight and close to the pin, making it easier to solder. Cut the sensor GND pins flush to keep things tidy.

steps.title: LED Strip GND Connection
steps.description: Connect the LED strip GND pads to the same ground bus.

steps.title: Solder LED Strip GND
steps.description: Solder GND wires to the LED strip GND pads.

steps.title: Solder Sensor GND
steps.description: Solder the ground wires to each sensor's GND pin.

steps.title: Solder GND Wires
steps.description: Continue soldering all GND connections row by row until every sensor and LED strip segment shares a common ground.

sections.title: Step 5 - Wiring: LED Strip Data & Power
sections.intro: Connect the LED data and 5V between LED strip segments, turning the 8 segments back into one continuous strip.

steps.title: Cover GND Wires
steps.description: Apply tape over the ground wires to insulate them and prevent shorts with other wires.

steps.title: Solder All LED Strip Wires
steps.description: Solder the LED data and 5V wires between each LED strip segment following the serpentine layout.

steps.title: Cover All LED Strip Wires
steps.description: Insulate all LED strip connections with tape to prevent shorts.

sections.title: Step 6 - Wiring: Sensor Row Wires
sections.intro: Connect the sensor output pins in each row. All 8 sensors in a row share one output wire that goes to an ESP32 GPIO pin.

steps.title: Pass Row Wires
steps.description: Thread row wires through the board as you did for the GND wires, connecting each sensor's output pin in the same row. I melted some PLA with my soldering iron over the wires to secure them in place.

steps.title: Solder Row Wires
steps.description: Solder each row wire to the output pin of every sensor in that row. Each row goes to a different ESP32 GPIO pin.

sections.title: Step 7 - Wiring: Sensor 5V (Column Power)
sections.intro: Connect each column's sensor VCC (5V) pins. These are driven by PNP transistors controlled by the shift register - only one column is powered at a time during scanning.

steps.title: Pass 5V Wires - Method 1
steps.description: First method: route the 5V wires through the wire guides along each column. Tape is required to insulate the 5V wires from the GND/row wires.

steps.title: Pass 5V Wires - Method 2 (Alternative)
steps.description: Alternative routing method for the 5V column wires - choose whichever you prefer. This spacer requires a thin ESP32 PCB to fit under the board, but allows easier wire routing on top of other GND/row wires, avoiding the need of tape to prevent shorts.

steps.title: Cut Extra Pin Length
steps.description: Trim the excess sensor pin length with flush cutters to keep things tidy and prevent shorts.

steps.title: Solder 5V Connections
steps.description: Solder the 5V wires to each sensor's VCC pin along the column. Each column wire will connect back to a transistor on the PCB (or to the shift register outputs if not using transistors)

sections.title: Step 8 - Plastic PCB Complete!
sections.intro: The board's sensor grid and LED array are now fully wired. Here's what the completed assembly looks like from different angles.

steps.title: All Wires Soldered
steps.description: Two perspectives showing the full sensor wiring - GND, row & column.

steps.title: Completed Plastic PCB
steps.description: Back and front views of the fully assembled plastic PCB - ready to be connected to the main ESP32 PCB.

sections.title: Step 9 - Chess Pieces: Magnets & Iron Discs
sections.intro: Prepare the chess pieces with embedded magnets and install iron discs under the board.

steps.title: Iron Disc Size
steps.description: 12√ó1mm iron discs - these sit under each square to spread the magnetic field from the piece's magnet, making detection possible across the whole square surface. They also keep the pieces in place.

steps.title: Glue Iron Discs
steps.description: Glue one iron disc centered on each of the 64 squares. Make sure they're flush against the board surface and securely attached.

steps.title: Glue magnets
steps.description: Glue one or two neodymium magnets into the bottom of each chess piece. The magnets should be flush with the piece's base for optimal detection. Make sure to orient the magnets with the south pole facing the board! To determine which side is the south pole, simply power the board and try both sides, only 1 side will work. TIP: you can use a hairdryer to soften the PLA plastic to make inserting magnets easier

sections.title: Step 10 - Board Finishing
sections.intro: Parchment paper can be used to diffuse the light. Do a test to make sure light shines evenly.

steps.title: Glue Parchment Paper
steps.description: Apply a sheet of parchment paper (baking paper) under each square. This acts as a light diffuser, spreading each LED's light evenly across the square ring, for a uniform glow without weird shadows.

steps.title: Light Test & Final Look
steps.description: Test how light shines through the rings. With no light backing the rings should not be visible.

sections.title: Step 11 - Main PCB Connection
sections.intro: Connect the board's wires to the main ESP32 PCB to bring everything to life.

steps.title: Apply Tape
steps.description: Use double-sided tape or insulating tape on the PCB mounting area to secure it and prevent shorts against the bare metal wires.

steps.title: PCB Placement
steps.description: Mount the main PCB in position. Ensure it's secure and the row/column wires are oriented correctly towards their soldering pads.

steps.title: Solder Rows & Columns to PCB
steps.description: Solder each row wire and column wire to the correct PCB pads. Double-check against the schematic - each row wire goes to a specific GPIO pin and each column goes to a transistor output (or shift register output if not using transistors).

software.title: Software Setup
software.intro: With the hardware built, flash the firmware to bring your chess board to life.

webInstaller.text: Don't want to install any tools? Use the Web Installer to flash your ESP32 directly from the browser (Chrome/Edge only). This is the fastest way to get started.

steps.title: 2. Configure
items: Open the .code-workspace file in VS Code
Edit GPIO pins in board_driver.h if using different pins than the default (pin order doesn't matter - calibration handles it)
Set SR_INVERT_OUTPUTS to 1 in board_driver.h if using PNP transistors
Optionally edit wifi_manager_esp32.h with your WiFi credentials (or set them later via the Web UI)

steps.title: 3. Flash
items: Follow the Serial Monitor instructions on first boot to calibrate the sensor grid

steps.title: 4. Play!
items: Power on the board - LEDs light up in the center for game selection

Place a piece on a lit square:
  • Blue - Human vs Human
  • Green - Human vs Stockfish
  • Yellow - Online (Lichess)
  • Red - Sensor Test

software.helpNote: Enable Serial Monitor at 115200 baud for detailed diagnostics. Check the GitHub repository for the latest updates and to report issues.
